text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

At BiGS leadership roundtable
in Sao Paulo recently,

we heard from CEOs and nonprofit
leaders across Latin America.

Join us as we explore how
businesses are not only

reshaping economies, but also
reshaping communities and lives
one investment at a time.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
My name is Enrique Téllez.

I'm the co-chair of
Desarrolladora Del Parque.

It's a developing company, a
real estate developer company

in Mexico City that does
residential and office spaces
in Mexico.

Currently, we're developing more
than 1,000,000 square meters
in the city.

Half of that is residential and
the other half is office space.

We currently have more
than 500 indirect employees
in the construction sites.

And then on the corporate side,
we have around 120 employees

helping us manage
Desarrolladora Del Parque.

Please tell us the
role that your company

plays in addressing
economic inequality.

You told me amazing
things about what

you're doing with pop-up
classrooms and such.

Within Desarrolladora
Del Parque,

we think that one
of the key roles

that we have is not only
serving our final consumer,

but I think much more
important, making sure

that our employee base,
be it direct or indirect,
grow with us.

And in particular, in the
construction industry,

where we hire people
to do our construction,

the construction workers
in Mexico, on average,

don't even have a primary
school certificate.

And we think that education
can make the change.

It can make a change
in the long run.

So we have decided to
invest in our people

through providing
education opportunities
for the construction workers.
What does this mean?

It means bringing in schools
to the construction sites

for these employees
that were not

able to finish their primary
school, middle school,
or high school.

So we provide with
a strategic partner

that comes in, a pop-up
classroom, teachers, and time

out of the schedule of the
construction workers to study.

And so they will be able to
finish their primary school,
middle school, and high school.

And I've seen, over
the 20 years that I've

been in the
construction industry,

in the development industry,
construction workers become
high school graduates.

Some of them even go to college
where we don't participate
anymore, but we know them.

And now they're engineers,
and they supervise.

They started as a
construction worker,

and now they're
supervising and designing

the work for other
colleagues of them.

Can you tell us the
story about one of them?

I'm sure you've attended
high school graduations.
Is there--
I mean, you want me to cry?
Yes.
No, no, it's very--
stories are very compelling.

We have a particular
story Juan Martínez,

who is a resident of
Apatzingan Hidalgo, which

is a very tiny town up in the
mountains, about three hours
away from Mexico City.

This is a person
that, unfortunately,

his father left them, so he
was raised by a single mother.

And he just had the opportunity
to finish primary school,

and then he had to help
his mother financially.

So because he didn't
have any other skill,

he entered the
construction work.

By the time I knew of
him, he must have been 19,
and he joined the program.

He really made an
effort to, in two years,

finish his middle school
and his high school
with a tremendous effort.
He graduated from high school.

And at the end of
it, he came and said,

licenciado, which is the way
they called us, and he said,

do you think I would
have an opportunity
to study in a university?

And I said, it's in your
hands, but the first thing

that you have to do is
apply to the university
to make sure you're accepted.

But if you made it all
the way to high school,

and you have put the effort into
it, you will be able to do it.

Three months later, I'm
visiting the construction site,

and he comes and says, I
already found the program
that I want to apply to.
Would you help me?
Of course.

Story short, five years later,
he graduated from engineering.

Today, he works directly
for us, supervising.

I couldn't be
prouder of somebody
that turned around his life.

Somebody that, in
a lasting manner,

changed his probabilities
and his family's

probabilities to
have a better life.

So in that sense, Barbara, I'm
a deep believer in education.

And as a business person and as
a co-owner of Desarrolladora Del

Parque, that is part
of our mission today.

So what should the business
role be is obviously,
we are set to create a profit.
We are not a not-for-profit.

We are a for-profit
organization.

But within our means, we have
to invest in our community

to have lasting changes for the
well-being of our co-workers
of Desarrolladora Del Parque.

Now, could a skeptic
say, Enrique,

you're training people
to leave you and not

fill of an important
construction job tomorrow.

Does this make sense
from a business lens?
In our case, it does.
And why does it?

Because we're still
in a situation where,

because not everybody
has the opportunity

to have access to a
continuous education

or get primary, secondary,
middle school and high school

and then be at a training
education or a formal education,

there is enough
supply of workers,
and we have to change that.

An education is a mean to
transforming societies,

or at least I'm a
believer on that.

I might be wrong, but
I'm a believer on that.

And so I think that is an
obligation that Desarrolladora
Del Parque has.

What you're doing
is incredibly hard.

So based on your
experience, what

is the one piece
of advice that you

would give to
business leaders who

may want to have a
mission like yours,

but they don't know how
to act or what to do?

Let me use ourselves
as a case base.

When our strategic
partner came and talked

about this opportunity of
having the pop-up classroom

in our construction site,
my two other partners

and myself turned around and
said, this is just a gimmick.
We don't want to invest in this.

There's going to
be costs involved.
There's going to be--

people are not going to
be working as they should,

or the companies that were
hiring to do the construction,

they're going to pop up
the cost of what we do.

And so our strategic
partner came and said, OK,

why don't we try one, and
if you have any regrets,

we'll pay you back whatever
you invest in the classroom

because we need the
classroom anyway.

We turned around,
OK, we'll do it.
The result was astonishing.

As in many businesses,
when you start a business,
you take a risk.

Obviously, you jump
into the unknown,

but with some
information into it.

No, it's not really
jumping into the unknown.

Here, we were jumping
also into the unknown.

We had the guarantee
that we would get back

whatever the pop-up
classroom cost,

which was nothing at
the end of the day.

But we had a guarantee that if
it didn't work, no harm done.

Be ready to take risks, but
more important, Barbara,

my advice is for
our colleagues, be

ready to invest
in your community

because the community
will make you stronger.

As satisfied customers
make your business stronger

and grow, having
strong communities make
your business also stronger.
That's what we need to do.

In the years to come, what
would you say, for your company

on this topic, would be
a challenge that you're
looking at and discussing?

I mean, for this to work,
there is a minimum scale

of construction site
because of the cost benefits
associated to it.

And I think something
that we need

to think about, given
economic cycles, sometimes,

you can have big
construction sites,

but there are cycles
where you have to work
on smaller construction sites.

We need to work with our
strategic partner, who

is a provider of the services,
to develop a cost-effective

classroom for smaller
construction sites.
I would say that's part of it.

The other challenge
is converting

other fellow developers to have
classrooms in their construction
sites.
Has that started to happen yet?

I have to admit, it's a
mouth-to-mouth process.

Not everyone believes
in the commitment

to the community and the
impact that you can have.
And we need to show them how.

As we were given the guarantee
that if it didn't work,

somebody was willing
to pay for it,

we need to create a sort of
guarantee that when you come in,

you'll have a return
on your investment.

Obviously, when
you tell the story,

it helps, but you have to go
and see it and convert them

with the impact, with similar
stories to the one I told you.
This is so fascinating.

Enrique, can you
please tell us, what

is the role that you think
business schools should

play in helping future
leaders understand
what their mission is?
Is this their responsibility?
Short answer, yes.

I believe that
business schools should
start changing the paradigm.

I think it's important because
when you go to a business

school, you will acquire skills
that will help you to become
a better business leader.

And if, in that
set of skills, we

develop the necessity
to transform

your community and your
obligation to do that,

in addition to creating
profits for your shareholders,

I think that will change the
mindset of future leaders
in Mexico or the world.
[CLOSING MUSIC PLAYING]
